pullRequest.title: SB Track2: Expose AMQP details ServiceBus Messages for sending and receiving.
pullRequest.bodyText:
Expose AMQP details ServiceBus Messages for sending and receiving.
API View : https://apiview.dev/Assemblies/Review/64f40be9988242c9a8facc8a20c5e9e7
fixes #14385

commit.message: Continue initial draft implementation: moved sbrm to models

nodes.bodyText: Inconsistent use of this. Why do the instantiation here vs in the constructor and make it final. We always do .getDeliveryAnnotations() when serialising or deserialising, so weren't not saving any time.
Is it necessary to have ("Data")? I think it would be just as informational to use .tostring on the enum value and get the value in all caps without adding complexity to this class..

nodes.bodyText: The body type is always data, you can return the enum rather than creating a new field variable for it for every instance.
iirc, we didn't have a public constructor available for this.
The arrangement should be the first set of new operators. And act would be the creation of the message.
Maybe a stupid question. There is class AmqpMessageHeader but no AmqpMessageFooter. What's the reason behind?
isDurable, like what we discussed in issue #14139
Similar to above, isFirstAcquirer

Two questions for this class.

Why do we want to wrap the data of a byte array into a class if we don't provide extra functionality than a byte array?
The constructor and every call of getData copy the bytes. This might waste some memory.
Is there a reason the other setters are boxed types and this is a primitive?
Similar question, you use boxed types on some of the other ones.
nit: new line

+        this.data = Arrays.copyOf(data, data.length);
+    }

+     * Gets the data.
+     *

nodes.bodyText: in general, I'd be consistent about when you're using "final" or not. This applies to all other areas of your code.
AmqpBodyType can be any of the three values, but here you are strict casting it to AmqpDataBody. This will fail for body types not AmqpBodyType.DATA.
It's always a single item collection. Why not add another one even though our current implementation layer does not support it.
This is only used once. You can move it into a method scope rather than having this global static live for the entire jvm lifetime. same with other instances where it is used once.
Why are these defined again? Don't we have a class with these.
TODO here
You need to format this.
This is an expensive operation. Every time we get the body, you're creating a new list with amqpdatabody then doing an array copy.
Why not assign (amqpMessage.getBody().getBodyType()) to a local variable? This will make it easier to read.
We already have a constants class.
This is going to be really hard to manage random static strings copied in 5 places.
I realised this constants are already defined in: AmqpMessageConstant in azure-core-amqp.
This is common, you can create a private method to aggregate these copied lines.

The point I was trying to make is that you know this data in the constructor. You can do this logic in the constructor and simply return a copy of the binary data.
Before, you were iterating through the Iterable of BinaryData each time, creating a new List object and then throwing it away to get the first item before copying it.
This incorrect.

I didn't mean to add to the public surface area so it fits our scenario. azure-core-amqp is generic to AMQP protocol. The support for a single BinaryData is an implementation detail because we use proton-j.

nodes.bodyText: This overhead of supporting amqp annotated message

commit.message: Added unit test case and general cleanup
Added unit test case and general cleanup

nodes.bodyText: This is not resolved. This one is still primitive, but all the other ones are boxed (ie. Boolean and Long). We should consolidate.
format document
nit: empty lines.
nit: empty lines
this.amqpAnnotatedMessage
We should test the actual BodyType of this. We may miss this which will result in a runtime exception when we move to support multiple types.
We should also make a copy of the annotated message rather than passing a reference to it or else they may change parts of the annotated message which affect other references of it.
This may be dealt with in a copy constructor for AmqpAnnotatedMessage.
for {@code getApplicationProperties()}
You already have a variable type, you don't need to reach in again and get it.
You can use a foreach loop instead of this?
Is there a reason we can't use a foreach loop for this?

You can just get it instead of doing two map accesses, doesn't work? Same with below.
return (String) dataMap.get(key);

do you have a test for that copy constructor? I have a feeling if you have a SBRMessage and start modifying annotated properties (ie. Subject), the original one will be modifed. (which isn't what you want).

Do we need a method for this? if we do assertNull, we won't understand which key failed, just that one of the keys was null when we did not want it to be. If we can split it out and reason about the lines
The extra message is not necessary. If this fails, we'll know the line that it failed at.
We don't need a protected method for this. It is only used once. Just put it in the arrangement.
Do we use this in our Batch size calculation as well?

commit.message: Added more check in unit test

nodes.bodyText: The local variable declaration is unnecessary.
What if they're trying to clear the scheduledEnqueueTime? Isn't null a value option to pass? Same with other instances.
You already have a local reference to the header, you can use that and go header.getDeliveryCount(). Same with other instances.
the period should be on the next line
this logic seems duplicated from lines 403
Did you update the changelog for azure-core-amqp
